R19.nl_constraint: City2 is out of fuel, planes can't refuel there

children.nl_constraint: Throughout the plan execution, no plane located in city2 should have fuel equal to its maximum capacity.

content.text:
<documents>
<pddl_domain>
;; Enrico Scala (enricos83@gmail.com) and Miquel Ramirez (miquel.ramirez@gmail.com)
(define (domain zenotravel)
        ;(:requirements :typing :fluents)
        (:types
                locatable city - object
                aircraft person - locatable
        )
        (:predicates
                (located ?x - locatable ?c - city)
                (in ?p - person ?a - aircraft)
        )
        (:functions
                (fuel ?a - aircraft)
                (distance ?c1 - city ?c2 - city)
                (slow-burn ?a - aircraft)
                (fast-burn ?a - aircraft)
                (capacity ?a - aircraft)
                (total-fuel-used)
                (onboard ?a - aircraft)
                (zoom-limit ?a - aircraft)

                (n_board ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                (n_debark ?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                (n_flyslow ?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                (n_flyfast ?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                (n_refuel ?a - aircraft)
        )

        (:action board
                :parameters (?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?p ?c)
                        (located ?a ?c))
                :effect (and (not (located ?p ?c))
                        (in ?p ?a)
                        (increase (onboard ?a) 1)
                        (increase (n_board ?p ?a ?c) 1))
        )

        (:action debark
                :parameters (?p - person ?a - aircraft ?c - city)
                :precondition (and (in ?p ?a)
                        (located ?a ?c))
                :effect (and (not (in ?p ?a))
                        (located ?p ?c)
                        (decrease (onboard ?a) 1)
                        (increase (n_debark ?p ?a ?c) 1))
        )

        (:action flyslow
                :parameters (?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?a ?c1)
                        (>= (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow-burn ?a))))
                :effect (and (not (located ?a ?c1))
                        (located ?a ?c2)
                        (increase
                                (total-fuel-used)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow-burn ?a)))
                        (decrease
                                (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (slow-burn ?a)))
                        (increase (n_flyslow ?a ?c1 ?c2) 1))
        )

        (:action flyfast
                :parameters (?a - aircraft ?c1 ?c2 - city)
                :precondition (and (located ?a ?c1)
                        (>= (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast-burn ?a)))
                        (<= (onboard ?a) (zoom-limit ?a)))
                :effect (and (not (located ?a ?c1))
                        (located ?a ?c2)
                        (increase
                                (total-fuel-used)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast-burn ?a)))
                        (decrease
                                (fuel ?a)
                                (* (distance ?c1 ?c2) (fast-burn ?a)))
                        (increase (n_flyfast ?a ?c1 ?c2) 1))
        )

        (:action refuel
                :parameters (?a - aircraft)
                :precondition (and (> (capacity ?a) (fuel ?a))

                )
                :effect (and (assign (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))
                        (increase (n_refuel ?a) 1))
        )

)
</pddl_domain>
<pddl_problem>
(define (problem ZTRAVEL-3-10)
(:domain zenotravel)
(:objects
	plane1 - aircraft
	plane2 - aircraft
	plane3 - aircraft
	person1 - person
	person2 - person
	person3 - person
	person4 - person
	person5 - person
	person6 - person
	person7 - person
	person8 - person
	person9 - person
	person10 - person
	city0 - city
	city1 - city
	city2 - city
	city3 - city
	city4 - city
	city5 - city
	)
(:init
	(located plane1 city4)
	(= (capacity plane1) 2326)
	(= (fuel plane1) 205)
	(= (slow-burn plane1) 1)
	(= (fast-burn plane1) 2)
	(= (onboard plane1) 0)
	(= (zoom-limit plane1) 10)
	(located plane2 city2)
	(= (capacity plane2) 12132)
	(= (fuel plane2) 1469)
	(= (slow-burn plane2) 4)
	(= (fast-burn plane2) 9)
	(= (onboard plane2) 0)
	(= (zoom-limit plane2) 9)
	(located plane3 city3)
	(= (capacity plane3) 5204)
	(= (fuel plane3) 1532)
	(= (slow-burn plane3) 2)
	(= (fast-burn plane3) 7)
	(= (onboard plane3) 0)
	(= (zoom-limit plane3) 8)
	(located person1 city1)
	(located person2 city2)
	(located person3 city1)
	(located person4 city4)
	(located person5 city5)
	(located person6 city1)
	(located person7 city0)
	(located person8 city2)
	(located person9 city1)
	(located person10 city5)
	(= (distance city0 city0) 0)
	(= (distance city0 city1) 619)
	(= (distance city0 city2) 565)
	(= (distance city0 city3) 886)
	(= (distance city0 city4) 596)
	(= (distance city0 city5) 766)
	(= (distance city1 city0) 619)
	(= (distance city1 city1) 0)
	(= (distance city1 city2) 561)
	(= (distance city1 city3) 756)
	(= (distance city1 city4) 760)
	(= (distance city1 city5) 980)
	(= (distance city2 city0) 565)
	(= (distance city2 city1) 561)
	(= (distance city2 city2) 0)
	(= (distance city2 city3) 657)
	(= (distance city2 city4) 702)
	(= (distance city2 city5) 639)
	(= (distance city3 city0) 886)
	(= (distance city3 city1) 756)
	(= (distance city3 city2) 657)
	(= (distance city3 city3) 0)
	(= (distance city3 city4) 546)
	(= (distance city3 city5) 510)
	(= (distance city4 city0) 596)
	(= (distance city4 city1) 760)
	(= (distance city4 city2) 702)
	(= (distance city4 city3) 546)
	(= (distance city4 city4) 0)
	(= (distance city4 city5) 850)
	(= (distance city5 city0) 766)
	(= (distance city5 city1) 980)
	(= (distance city5 city2) 639)
	(= (distance city5 city3) 510)
	(= (distance city5 city4) 850)
	(= (distance city5 city5) 0)
	(= (total-fuel-used) 0)
)
(:goal (and
	(located plane1 city4)
	(located person1 city4)
	(located person2 city5)
	(located person3 city4)
	(located person4 city0)
	(located person5 city2)
	(located person6 city3)
	(located person8 city0)
	(located person9 city3)
	(located person10 city4)
	))

(:metric minimize (total-fuel-used))





)
</pddl_problem>
</documents> 

<information>
The user will give as input a natural language constraint that must be translated into PDDL3.0. The translation will be used by a PDDL planner.
</information>

<instructions> 
- Translate the input constraint into correct PDDL3.0.
- The resulting PDDL3.0 constraint must capture the same meaning as the initial input constraint.
- Remember that PDDL3.0 constraints are state-based. They can only refer to existing precates and fluents, thus, not to actions.
- Be sure to include temporal logic like operators in your translation.
- Format your answer such as there is no preambule and such that the PDDL translation is between the tags <pddl> and </pddl>.
</instructions>

<user_input>
Throughout the plan execution, no plane located in city2 should have fuel equal to its maximum capacity.
</user_input>

The user wants me to translate the constraint "Throughout the plan execution, no plane located in city2 should have fuel equal to its maximum capacity" into PDDL3.0.

Let me break this down:
1. "Throughout the plan execution" - this indicates a temporal constraint that must hold for the entire duration of the plan, which in PDDL3.0 would be represented using the "always" operator
2. "no plane located in city2" - this refers to aircraft objects that are located in city2
3. "should have fuel equal to its maximum capacity" - this means the fuel of the aircraft should not equal its capacity

In PDDL3.0, temporal constraints use operators like:
- always (condition) - condition must hold throughout the entire plan
- sometime (condition) - condition must hold at some point during the plan
- at-most-once (condition) - condition can hold at most once during the plan
- sometime-after (condition1) (condition2) - condition2 must hold sometime after condition1
- sometime-before (condition1) (condition2) - condition1 must hold sometime before condition2

Since we want this to hold "throughout the plan execution", we need to use "always".

The condition we want to negate is: for any aircraft ?a, if (located ?a city2) then NOT (= (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))

In PDDL3.0, this would be:
always (forall (?a - aircraft) (imply (located ?a city2) (not (= (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a)))))

Wait, let me double check the syntax. In PDDL3.0, constraints are typically written in the (:constraints) section and use temporal logic operators.

The constraint should be:
always (forall (?a - aircraft) (imply (located ?a city2) (not (= (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a)))))

This reads as: "Always, for all aircraft a, if a is located in city2, then the fuel of a is not equal to the capacity of a."


I'll refine the constraint to precisely capture the temporal requirement. The key is using the "always" temporal operator to ensure the condition holds throughout the entire plan execution. The logical structure uses a universal quantifier (forall) with an implication to specify the condition for planes in city2.

<information>
The user will give as input a constraint in natural language. This constraint must be used as a transjectory hard constraint for the solution plan of the given the PDDL problem. 
</information>

<instructions> 
- Refine the user constraint to make it applicable to the given PDDL problem.
- You can rephrase and decompose the initial constraint into several other contraints.
- These constraints should be complementary and they will be later combined with AND operators.
- Constraints must be state-based and follow a Linear Temporal Logic. So constraints can't directly refer to actions.
- Avoid explicit PDDL language in your answer, the user can't understand PDDL.
- The set of all refined constraints must capture the meaning of the initial user constraint. 
- Format your answer as a clear and concise numbered list between the tags <constraints> and </constraints>. There should be no subitems, only the list of refined constraints.
- After, add 1 or 2 sentences to explain your choice of decomposition between the tags <explanation> and </explanation>.
- Here is an example of how to format your answer:
    <constraints>
        1. [natural_language_constraint_1]
        2. [natural_language_constraint_2]
        ...
    </constraints>
    <explanation>
        [consice_explanation]
    </explanation>
</instructions>

<user_input>
City2 is out of fuel, planes can't refuel there
</user_input>

Let me analyze the user constraint: "City2 is out of fuel, planes can't refuel there"

Looking at the PDDL domain, I can see there's a refuel action:
```
(:action refuel
    :parameters (?a - aircraft)
    :precondition (and (> (capacity ?a) (fuel ?a))
    )
    :effect (and (assign (fuel ?a) (capacity ?a))
            (increase (n_refuel ?a) 1))
)
```

The refuel action doesn't have any location-based preconditions in the domain definition, which means normally planes can refuel anywhere they are located. However, the user wants to constrain this so that planes cannot refuel when they are in city2.

Since I need to create state-based constraints (not action-based), I need to think about this differently. The constraint is essentially saying that if a plane is located in city2, it should not be able to refuel there.

However, since constraints are state-based and follow Linear Temporal Logic, I can't directly reference the refuel action. Instead, I need to think about what states would be inconsistent with this constraint.

The constraint "planes can't refuel there" means that if a plane is in city2, it should not increase its fuel level to its maximum capacity (which is what refueling does).

So I could rephrase this as:
- If a plane is located in city2, then its fuel level should not jump to its maximum capacity
- Or more generally: No plane should refuel while located in city2

But since I need state-based constraints, I should focus on the states that would indicate refueling has occurred in city2.

Actually, let me think about this more carefully. The user constraint is about preventing refueling in city2. Since the refuel action sets fuel to capacity, I could express this as:

"If a plane is located in city2, then its fuel should not be equal to its capacity (unless it arrived there already at full capacity)"
 
This approach might be overly restrictive, as planes could legitimately arrive in city2 with full fuel tanks. I'll explore alternative interpretations that capture the core constraint more precisely.

The most direct state-based formulation would focus on preventing fuel increases while in city2. This means creating a constraint that ensures no plane can have its fuel level maximized during its stay in the location.

I'm considering a nuanced definition that allows planes already at full capacity to remain in city2, while preventing any refueling actions that would bring a plane to maximum fuel levels. The key is distinguishing between planes arriving full versus those being refueled to full capacity during their stay.

The constraint essentially aims to block refueling operations in city2, which suggests a rule preventing fuel from reaching maximum levels through any action while in that specific location.

My current approach focuses on state-based logic: a plane in city2 cannot have its fuel set to maximum capacity through an action, preserving flexibility for planes that naturally arrive at full fuel.

This requires carefully parsing the difference between a plane's initial state versus actions that would artificially maximize its fuel during its city2 presence. The goal is a precise, actionable constraint that prevents refueling without unnecessarily restricting plane movements.

By specifying that no plane in city2 can transition to a full fuel state, I'm creating a nuanced rule that blocks refueling while allowing natural flight dynamics. The constraint targets the specific mechanism of fuel replenishment without overly rigid limitations.

The initial plane configurations - plane1 at city4 with 205 fuel, plane2 at city2 with 1469 fuel - provide concrete context for testing this constraint's practical application.

Examining plane2's initial state reveals an important detail: its current fuel is below capacity, which means my proposed rule wouldn't interfere with its starting condition. This observation validates the constraint's precision in addressing the refueling prevention goal.

<constraints>
1. Throughout the plan execution, no plane located in city2 should have fuel equal to its maximum capacity.
</constraints>

<explanation>
This constraint prevents planes from refueling while in city2 by ensuring they cannot reach the state that results from refueling (fuel at maximum capacity) while located there. This effectively blocks the refuel operation in city2 while still allowing planes to visit the city with partial fuel.
</explanation>
